Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
India has a strange partnership with a brutal dictator

Syria's Bashar al-Assad was an Indian partner for years

His fall from power could be worrying for India

Here's why🧵 https://t.co/JPGn5kk2LK
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
Syria's Bashar al-Assad is one of the world's most hated dictators

For the last 13 years, Syria has been torn apart by a brutal civil war

Assad has been isolated by many global powers for his actions

His govt has fallen apart

But India has continued to work with Assad
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
The Syrian civil war began as a revolt against corruption and repression under Assad's regime

Assad responded with brutality

He is accused of using chemical weapons against his people and illegally arresting thousands

Millions of Syrians fled the country as the war escalated
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
Many global powers have isolated Bashar al-Assad and Syria

In 2011, Syria was expelled from the Arab League

Major Western powers (including the US) slapped sanctions on Assad's govt

Now, Assad's govt seems set to collapse as opposition forces have decimated his army
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
Only a handful of countries have actually maintained ties with Assad and Syria

India is one of those countries

It has provided millions of dollars in humanitarian aid to Syria's govt - especially after the 2023 earthquakes there

India has also maintained high level contacts
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
Syria's Foreign Minister visited India in 2023 and top Indian diplomats have been to Syria

At the United Nations, India has voted against sanctions on Assad's regime

It also pushed for foreign powers not to get involved in Syria's civil war

So why did India do this?
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
1⃣. History

India and Syria have worked together for decades

Both countries were founding members of the Non-Aligned Movement

India's foreign policy after 1947 was broadly pro-Arab

Prime Ministers like Nehru and Vajpayee visited Syria and built close ties to its leaders
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
This meant that India had established interests in working with Syria

For example - at the time the Syrian civil war began in 2011 - India was providing $240 million to develop the Tishreen Power Plant

That history with Bashar Al-Assad and his father Hafez has kept ties going
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
2⃣. Stability

The Syrian civil war began as part of the Arab Spring movement

Countries across the Arab world saw mass public protests calling for the fall of dictatorships and new democratic govts

However, in some countries like Libya, things went badly wrong
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
Western powers backed the overthrow of Libya's dictator Muammar Gaddafi

However, the country descended into civil war instead of becoming a stable democracy

India wanted to ensure that Syria did not go the same way

That's because India has key interests in the Middle East
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
This includes energy supplies, economic investments and political relationships with Middle Eastern nations

It also has ~9 million Indians living in the region

So India wants stability

When the war in Syria broke out, India tried to reduce foreign pressure on Assad
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
At the United Nations, India refused to back sanctions against Syria

It condemned violence by both Assad and rebel forces

And it supported non-interference by foreign powers in Syria

All of this has been appreciated by the Assad govt
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
3⃣. Terrorism

The Syrian civil war also led to the rise of the Islamic State

In 2014, ISIS rapidly took over large parts of Syria and established its own govt

This prompted foreign intervention - America and Russia both started direct military involvement in the conflict
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
The rise of ISIS posed a threat to India too as the group has tried to carry out attacks there

India has expressed some support for Russian military strikes to destroy ISIS

Over the last few years, ISIS power in Syria has been shattered
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
4⃣. Kashmir

Interestingly, Syria has been supportive of India's position on the Kashmir conflict

It has stated that Kashmir is an internal issue for India to deal with

This makes it a useful partner since Pakistan often turns to the Islamic world for support on Kashmir
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
All of this explains why India has continued to work with Assad

His fall from power does bring uncertainty

As Kabir Taneja points out, there is so far no Plan-B for what happens after Assad

There is little unity among Syria's opposition forces - which could cause more conflict
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
The rise of Syria's rebel groups will be a concern

This is particularly true of Abu al-Jolani, the leader of the HTS rebel group, which toppled Assad from power

Jolani has past links to the Islamic State - which does raise questions about extremism if he leads a new govt
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
While these are key concerns for India, it is too early to tell what a new Syrian govt will look like or who will lead it 

But as it has in the past, India will find a way to work with whichever regime happens to be in power
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal

Name: Shashank Mattoo
TweetText:
If you enjoy content like this, please do consider following me (@MattooShashank) on Twitter!

I'm also on Instagram: https://t.co/uNvJ2xYeId
Bio: Foreign Affairs for @IndiaToday @ITGGlobal | Formerly - @livemint @orfonline | MPhil @Cambridge_Uni | Kashmiri Pandit | Views Personal
